body: the memory leak may be fixed in 1.7.1. I test this version already one week, it works fine.
@luchunminglu I download from https://github.com/grpc/grpc recently. I don't sure if it's 1.7.1.
@luchunminglu I test it on version 1.7.2, it has the same promble
I just test the c++ greeter_async_client2 and greeter_async_server. it has the same promble.

I am having the same problem here. In my case, I used sync clients and sync servers (like helloworld client/server). 1K of request, 0.7% of memory (56MB of 8GB) passing one boolean from the client to the server.

Any idea??

Same here, I can provide a demo script if this would help.

The server just eats all my memory ;)

Does the problem this still persist in 1.8.3?
Is it centos specific on you're seeing it on other linux distributions as well?
@jtattermusch I haven't test on 1.8.3 yet. And also just test on centos7. I will test it when I am free.
@Rhysol, I know it's been a while. Do you still see this issue. Can you make your demo code available?
@srini100 I have found my code and upload to my repository. But I don't know if it's ok. I havn't test it a long while. https://github.com/Rhysol/GrpcDemo
@trusch - can you provide the repro script that you mentioned also?
I'm sorry but it's been a while. When I remember correctly I worked around by reusing existing connections.

@vjpai @hcaseyal I can see the memory leak by running the async server and async client examples. Server keeps holding more and more memory even after client RPCs are done. Sometimes it releases some memory when client disconnects but most of the times it just accumulates the memory.
![alloc_trace](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/35056280/39477854-660c5064-4d15-11e8-8dd0-d15170d562d0.png)
Marking this as P1 until we have better understanding of memory usage.
@srini100 which version do you use?
1.10 as well as latest on master.
Since grpc server is a long running backend process, memory leak is quite a serious issue. Do we have any schedule when to fix it?  @vjpai

This is being actively looked into.

On Sat, May 5, 2018 at 12:30 PM zhenglin tao <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Since grpc server is a long running backend process, memory leak is quite
> a serious issue. Do we have any schedule when to fix it?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/13319#issuecomment-386773048>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AIibUnVhlPHekUZgE51gFGrZIhGiqbjVks5tvQ6ugaJpZM4QXfud>
> .
>
Great!
@hcaseyal @dgquintas we encountered the same memory leak issue, and it is blocking our work. it would be great if it can be fixed soon. Thanks.
@changleicn Could you provide a repro and your environment (including compiler / OS version)?

I have tried reproducing the issue with the async client and server examples under various tooling (valgrind on Linux, activity monitor on Mac, and internal tools) and did not see the server holding memory after client RPCs were done. Top disagrees, but that's because glibc is probably holding on to the freed memory and not relinquishing it to the OS.

@changleicn As mentioned above, we have thoroughly investigated the async case using external as well as internal tools that track detailed memory usage. Our conclusion is that gRPC server is not holding onto any more memory than it should after all RPCs have completed. 

I am closing this issue, but if you are able to provide the specific reproduction case along with the tools you used to show the memory blow up, feel free to re open and we will take another look.
@changleicn, if you are using glibc have you tried playing with malloc threshold parameters to free the memory to OS?

@hcaseyal Have you monitored the client side? In my case the leak is not in server side, but in client side. I start up my user process which owns several rpc clients, also there is one completion queue thread which is shared by all these rpc clients. When rpc clients disconnects, my user process still owns quite a lot of memory which exists in grpc, maybe in cq part.
@srini100 Does it work? If so, could you please help share this? currently I am blocked by the memory leak in grpc client side.

@ztao1987 I could see no evidence of a memory leak in client side either. If you think there is a memory leak in grpc, could you please include more information so that I can help you? I.e., a specific reproduction case (code would help), the tools you used to show memory blow up, and OS and compiler version. 
Could you also share how it is blocking you? E.g., are you oom-ing?

![wechatimg69](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11328679/40090796-9944dbea-58e6-11e8-9869-872e9ee87a3e.jpeg)
I tested on mac os 10.11.6, seems GrpcBufferReader continues to hold the memory.
